newsitem.title: USA: U.S. home-ownership rate rises to highest in 15 years.
newsitem.headline: U.S. home-ownership rate rises to highest in 15 years.

text.p: The U.S. home-ownership rate climbed to its highest level in 15 years in the third quarter as 66.3 million American households now own their own homes, the government announced on Tuesday.
It said the percentage of American households that own their own homes rose to 65.6 percent in the third quarter from 65.4 percent in the second.
That marked the tenth straight quarterly rise and brought the homeownership rate to its highest level since the third quarter of 1981, when it also stood at 65.6 percent.
President Clinton immediately took credit for the rise and pledged further measures to boost home-ownership if re-elected to another four-year term on Nov. 5.
"My administration has worked hard to help more Americans own their own home," Clinton said. "Now we must do more."

Campaign officials for Bob Dole had no immediate comment on the home-ownership figure, a relatively obscure economic statistic that has been elevated in importance by the Clinton administration during this election year.
White House Chief Economic Adviser Laura Tyson told reporters that the rise in home-ownership resulted from the strong economy and low level of interest rates under Clinton.
However, Republican lawmakers in the past have argued that it was their focus on balancing the budget that has kept long-term interest rates, including mortgage rates, down.
